unnormalised: What's the difference between Dr. and a MBBS?
normalised: What's the difference between Doctor and a M-B-B-S?

unnormalised: Okay, so let's break this down a bit, especially for those considering a career in medicine in India. Basically, MBBS is a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery - it's the degree you get after completing your undergraduate medical education. Think of it like your B.Tech or B.Com, but for doctors. Passing the MBBS is what allows you to register with the Medical Council and officially practice medicine as a general practitioner.
normalised: Okay, so, let's break this down a bit, especially for those considering a career in medicine in India. Basically, M-B-B-S is a Bachelor of Medicine and Bachelor of Surgery - it's the degree you get after completing your undergraduate medical education. Think of it like your B-Tech or B-Com, but for doctors. Passing the M-B-B-S is what allows you to register with the Medical Council and officially practice medicine as a general practitioner.

unnormalised: "Dr." is a title, and it can be a bit confusing. While someone with an MBBS is absolutely entitled to use the title "Dr.", it's also used by individuals holding a doctorate degree, like a PhD. So, while Dr. Sharma with an MBBS can treat your cold, Dr. Gupta with a PhD in Biochemistry might be researching the underlying mechanisms of disease. Also, after the MBBS, many doctors pursue postgraduate degrees like MD (Doctor of Medicine) or MS (Master of Surgery) in a specific field like Cardiology or General Surgery. These individuals would also use the title Dr. So, Dr. Kapoor, MD (Cardiology) is a cardiologist, a heart specialist.
normalised: "Doctor" is a title, and it can be a bit confusing. While someone with an M-B-B-S is absolutely entitled to use the title "Doctor", it's also used by individuals holding a doctorate degree, like a P-h-D. So, while Doctor Sharma with an M-B-B-S can treat your cold, Doctor Gupta with a P-h-D in Biochemistry might be researching the underlying mechanisms of disease. Also, after the M-B-B-S, many doctors pursue postgraduate degrees like M-D (Doctor of Medicine) or M-S (Master of Surgery) in a specific field like Cardiology or General Surgery. These individuals would also use the title Doctor. So, Doctor Kapoor, M-D (Cardiology) is a cardiologist, a heart specialist.

unnormalised: So, in short, MBBS is the basic medical degree. "Dr." is a title applicable to those holding an MBBS, postgraduate medical degrees (MD, MS, etc.), or a doctorate (PhD). Knowing the context can usually help you understand what kind of "Dr." someone is! It's always a good idea to check credentials, especially when seeking medical advice.
normalised: So, in short, M-B-B-S is the basic medical degree. "Doctor" is a title applicable to those holding an M-B-B-S, postgraduate medical degrees (M-D, M-S, etcetera), or a doctorate (P-h-D). Knowing the context can usually help you understand what kind of "Doctor" someone is! It's always a good idea to check credentials, especially when seeking medical advice.
